specJson.name: brightics.function.clustering$gaussian_mixture_train
specJson.label: Gaussian Mixture Train
specJson.description:
A Gaussian mixture model is a probabilistic model that assumes all the data points are generated from a mixture of a finite number of Gaussian distributions with unknown parameters. One can think of mixture models as generalizing k-means clustering to incorporate information about the covariance structure of the data as well as the centers of the latent Gaussians.

- Pros : It is the fastest algorithm for learning mixture models. As this algorithm maximizes only the likelihood, it will not bias the means towards zero, or bias the cluster sizes to have specific structures that might or might not apply.

- Cons : When one has insufficiently many points per mixture, estimating the covariance matrices becomes difficult, and the algorithm is known to diverge and find solutions with infinite likelihood unless one regularizes the covariances artificially. This algorithm will always use all the components it has access to, needing held-out data or information theoretical criteria to decide how many components to use in the absence of external cues.

Reference:
+ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixture_model#Gaussian_mixture_model>
+ <https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.mixture.GaussianMixture.html>

params.label: Input Columns
params.description: Input column names. Only values in numeric type are possible.

params.label: Covariance Type
params.description:
String describing the type of covariance parameters to use. Must be one of:

 Full : each component has its own general covariance matrix
 Tied : all components share the same general covariance matrix
 Diagonal : each component has its own diagonal covariance matrix
 Spherical : each component has its own single variance

params.label: Tolerance
params.description: The convergence threshold. EM iterations will stop when the lower bound average gain is below this threshold.

params.label: Regularization of Covariance
params.description: Non-negative regularization added to the diagonal of covariance. Allows to assure that the covariance matrices are all positive.

params.label: Number of Iteration
params.description: The number of EM iterations to perform.

params.label: Method to Initialize
params.description:
The method used to initialize the weights, the means and the precisions. Must be one of:

K-means : responsibilities are initialized using kmeans.
Random : responsibilities are initialized randomly.

params.label: Seed
params.description: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results.

specJson.summary: This function trains an gaussian mixture clustering model.

md: # Gaussian Mixture Train This function trains an gaussian mixture clustering model. ## Description A Gaussian mixture model is a probabilistic model that assumes all the data points are generated from a mixture of a finite number of Gaussian distributions with unknown parameters. One can think of mixture models as generalizing k-means clustering to incorporate information about the covariance structure of the data as well as the centers of the latent Gaussians. - Pros : It is the fastest algorithm for learning mixture models. As this algorithm maximizes only the likelihood, it will not bias the means towards zero, or bias the cluster sizes to have specific structures that might or might not apply. - Cons : When one has insufficiently many points per mixture, estimating the covariance matrices becomes difficult, and the algorithm is known to diverge and find solutions with infinite likelihood unless one regularizes the covariances artificially. This algorithm will always use all the components it has access to, needing held-out data or information theoretical criteria to decide how many components to use in the absence of external cues. Reference: + + ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. It must contain at least one column for labels. #### OUTPUT 1. **model**: (Model) Trained Gaussian Mixture model. #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Columns***: Input column names. Only values in numeric type are possible. 2. **Number of Components**: The number of mixture components. 3. **Covariance Type**: String describing the type of covariance parameters to use. Must be one of: * `Full` : each component has its own general covariance matrix * `Tied` : all components share the same general covariance matrix * `Diagonal` : each component has its own diagonal covariance matrix * `Spherical` : each component has its own single variance 4. **Tolerance**: The convergence threshold. EM iterations will stop when the lower bound average gain is below this threshold. 5. **Regularization of Covariance**: Non-negative regularization added to the diagonal of covariance. Allows to assure that the covariance matrices are all positive. 6. **Number of Iteration**: The number of EM iterations to perform. 7. **Method to Initialize**: The method used to initialize the weights, the means and the precisions. Must be one of: * `K-means` : responsibilities are initialized using kmeans. * `Random` : responsibilities are initialized randomly. 8. **Seed**: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results. 9. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` gaussian_mixture_train(table, input_cols, number_of_components=1, covariance_type='full', tolerance=0.001,regularize_covariance=0.000001, max_iteration=100, initial_params='kmeans', seed=None, group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. It must contain at least one column for labels. #### OUTPUT 1. **model**: (Model) Trained Gaussian Mixture model. #### PARAMETER 1. **input_cols***: Input column names. Only values in numeric type are possible. * Type: *list[str]* 2. **number_of_components**: The number of mixture components. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 1 (value >= 1) 3. **covariance_type**: String describing the type of covariance parameters to use. Must be one of: * `full` : each component has its own general covariance matrix * `tied` : all components share the same general covariance matrix * `diagonal` : each component has its own diagonal covariance matrix * `spherical` : each component has its own single variance * Type: *str* * Default / Range: full ( full | tied | diag | spherical ) 4. **tolerance**: The convergence threshold. EM iterations will stop when the lower bound average gain is below this threshold. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: 0.001 (value > 0) 5. **regularize_covariance**: Non-negative regularization added to the diagonal of covariance. Allows to assure that the covariance matrices are all positive. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: 0.000001 (value > 0) 6. **max_iteration**: The number of EM iterations to perform. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 100 (value >= 1) 7. **initial_params**: The method used to initialize the weights, the means and the precisions. Must be one of: * `kmeans` : responsibilities are initialized using kmeans. * `random` : responsibilities are initialized randomly. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: kmeans ( kmeans | random ) 8. **seed**: Random seed. Use the same seed in order to reproduce the same results. * Type: *int* * Default value: None 9. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* * Default value: None ## Example ### VA **[Related Tutorial]** **[Sample Model]** In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used to train a gaussian mixture. The generated model is afterward applied to a test data set to predict the cluster of data, by using Gaussian Mixture Predict function. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Columns***: sepal_length, sepal_width 2. **Number of Components**: 3 3. **Covariance Type**: Full 4. **Tolerance**: 0.001 5. **Regularization of Covariance**: 0.000001 6. **Number of Iteration**: 100 7. **Method to Initialize**: K-means 8. **Seed**: None 9. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.clustering import gaussian_mixture_train input_table = inputs[0] result = gaussian_mixture_train(table=input_table, input_cols=['sepal_width', 'sepal_length'], number_of_components=3, covariance_type='full', tolerance=0.001, regularize_covariance=0.000001, max_iteration=100, initial_params='kmeans', seed=None, group_by=None) output = result['model'] ``` In this python script, sample_iris data is used to train a gaussian mixture. The generated model can be applied to a test data set to predict the cluster of data, by using Gaussian Mixture Predict function.
